page.content: blackspot through Trade decline. But this was overcome as it was forced to join up with the great canal because it would not be able to survive the competition otherwise. However by 1798 interests and attention were diverted to the Napoleonic Wars, so in the meantime the project was laid aside. By 1813 there was a high price in coal so interest in the canal was revived and Hugh Baird was commissioned to look into it. It was not until 1817 that the Union Canal Act was passed. But at the Edinburgh end work did not begin until 1818. The first passenger boat to operate between Edinburgh and Ratho was in 1822 and she was called the Flora MacIvor.
